awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase II:  A suite of flexible printed MRI coils for newborn to adult patients
awd_abstract_narration:
This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project aims to develop a suite of screen-printed receive coils for Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI), that are flexible, lightweight, low-cost and adapted to the entire population from infants to adults. MRI is widely used to establish a broad variety of clinical diagnosis, but suffers from long examination times and a high rate of failure, resulting in a yearly loss of more than $4 billion in the United States alone. Printed receive coils are extremely flexible, lightweight, and conform well to the human body. With this technology, coils can be designed and manufactured inexpensively to fit all patient sizes, thus improving image quality and enabling robust acceleration of the method. These benefits can contribute to increase the success rate of MRI exams, speed up procedure time, enhance the clinical workflow, and reduce equipment costs. Printed coils will improve the quality of care offered by MRI suites and increase the availability and use of MRI to a wider patient population. Overall, this project will develop a clinical-ready system capable of delivering the full economic and clinical benefits of printed coils, which will contribute to a reduction of the healthcare costs associated with MRI.

This project aims to fully realize a clinical-ready system consisting of a collection of printed, flexible lightweight MRI coil arrays, and connecting to a single universal cable to interface with the MRI scanner. A first part of the project will focus on the design of the cable and the associated connection scheme allowing interchange of multiple printed coil arrays of different sizes. Different strategies will be examined with the intent of maintaining high performance and safety while maximizing the advantages brought by printing. A second project goal will focus on the development of a collection of printed coil arrays for patient sizes ranging from newborn to adult, that are compatible with the universal cable and for both 3T and 1.5T scanners. The arrays will be designed for body imaging and will consist of 32-channel devices divided into 16-channel posterior and anterior portions. Their performance will be compared to a commercial 32-channel product. The final system will meet all the safety requirements for medical use and will be ready to be manufactured at scale.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) is an excellent clinical tool, as it provides high dynamic range for soft tissue contrast and full volumetric data without the use of ionizing radiation. It is routinely used for clinical imaging, with more than 40 million exams performed in the US every year. Functional and structural data provided by MRI have become a major part of clinical diagnostics and disease monitoring. However, several drawbacks still limit the full potential of MR imaging, especially among pediatric patients where the reduction of ionizing radiation in imaging is most important. Long exam times, high patient anxiety or low patient compliance which then require anesthesia for imaging, and a high incidence of scan failures all contribute to a reduction of MRI for clinical imaging of pediatric patients. In MRI, accessories called receive coils are used to capture image data during the exams. In order to optimize image quality these coils are placed directly over the anatomy of interest. Ideally, these coils should also be comfortable and easy to set up in order to improve workflow, and should conform tightly to the body of each patient to achieve high quality images quickly. However, in practice these coils often become a significant contributor to the shortcomings of MR imaging. Because they are expensive MRI suites typically have a limited number of coils, and adult coils are often the only hardware available to most pediatric patients. Adult coils are usually bulky, semi-rigid, and poorly sized for small patients. This often results in additional setup time, patient discomfort and claustrophobia. All of which results in higher rates of failed exams in pediatric populations, higher risk from the use of anesthesia, and lower quality clinical images. Together, these factors limit the use of MRI for pediatrics, both in hospitals and in research environments.

The objective of this project was to develop a new solution for MRI coil arrays. After demonstrating in Phase I that MRI coils can be constructed out of printed electronics in place of traditional electronics without sacrificing imaging performance, this project aimed to develop that technology into a marketable product for pediatric imaging. This technology represents a radical change from what is currently on the market, with a focus on lightweight flexible packaging and patient-friendly design. Development of novel circuit designs, optimization of printed electronics for MR, and focus on mechanical robust packaging that is optimized for the MR environment resulted in a novel pediatric imaging device ready for clinical use. The completed device - a 24-channel printed, flexible, lightweight array for pediatric body and cardiac imaging - was granted FDA 510(k) clearance and is now available for sales in the US. This device is optimized for small bodies, allowing technologists and radiologists to make better use of their scanners by generating higher quality images or reducing scan time. The flexible, lightweight, patient-friendly design provides a more familiar experience for pediatric patients, reducing anxiety and claustrophobia which may otherwise result in the use of anesthesia or in exam failure. 

The technology optimized during this project is also highly adaptable. Based in printed electronics and RF design optimization, this technology is easily transferable to different coil sizes, imaging regions of interest, and body anatomies for optimized MRI hardware for all patients. In parallel with the development of our first commercial product, research on transferring this technology to other frequencies, coil sizes, and array layouts was also completed. This work will be the foundation for the development of our next device, increasing the sizes and shapes of InkSpace Imaging coils available on the market.


 

 


Last Modified: 03/23/2022
Modified by: Joseph R Corea

Image
  • Three pediatric clinical images are shown, demonstrating good image quality obtained with a printed flexible RF coil array.
    InkSpace Imaging
    Copyrighted
    Joseph R Corea
    InkSpace Imaging 24-channel pediatric coil
